text: Bottle by alexsdad06. Poured clear dark ruby brown color with an average frothy tan head that mostly lasted with very good lacing. Moderate to heavy toasted malt and dark fruit with a sour aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy toasted complex dark sour flavor with a medium to heavy complex sour finish of moderate to long duration. This beer exceeded my expectations.

Pours opaque chocolate with a minimal buff head. Aroma features tart dark fruit and toasted malt notes. Flavor offers tart dark fruit, toasty malt, and subtle woody hops. Mouthfeel presents nice fizz and body, as well as a tart dark fruit finish. Shadow the eyes.

750 ml bottle shared with Tmoney99 and the Nine Giant crew. Pours a clear brown amber color with a small off white head that disappeared quickly. The aroma and flavor have tart dark fruits, vinous character, some acetic character, oak, soft middle, better at the finish.

Pours dark brown with low tanned head 
Aromas of vinous dark fruits, burned caramel, almond icing, hints of leather , sour cherries 
Taste has very nice tart notes sour cherries, burned caramel, oak, vinous raisins, red berries, vanilla

2017 version at 7.0 % abv. Pours black with a medium off white head. Aromas of almond, dark fruits, burnt caramel, cherries. Taste is very fruity and quite sour with slight burnt and oak notes. Mouthfeel is moderately bodied with medium carbonation.

Extreme Beer Fest 2017. Pours a moderately dark brown with a small beige head that leaves good lacing. Nose is of roasted malt, red wine and actually pretty pleasing. Some chocolate. Taste is of grapes, red wine, roasted malt and again pretty nice. Moderately tart. Body is medium, carbonation moderate. Vinous. I enjoyed this one quite a bit!
Bottle - Dark sour cherry and plum notes. Dark brown opaque with a small beige head. Acidic up front, plum and prune. Dark and acidic, not nearly as nice as the nose.

750ml bottle @ Matts. Pours a cloudy and murky dark brown with a thin tan head. Nose is sour toward the lacto sense with an oaky note. Flavour is a nice upfront sourness, some tangy acetic character that isnt quite balsamic, and some dark fruits. Quite enjoyable.
750ml bottle at Matts. Pours a very dark brown with tan head. Aroma is balsamic, woody, some cherries. Taste is similar. Moderate to high sourness. Quite good, but I would prefer less acidity.

750mL bottle, pours black with a small beige head. Aroma brings out lots of leather upfront, with tart dark fruits, chocolate and tobacco. Flavour is pleasant, with a nice mix of leather, tart dark fruits and tobacco upfront, and then the vinegary and acidic character comes in ever so slowly, eventually dominating the palate, lingering on and on. A little harsh, but its pleasant enough.

Light brown, no head. Bit hazy. The aroma is a bit woody, hint of cocoa, and while it hints at tartness, it is also showing balance. On the palate, this is typically really sour. Maybe a touch of brett. Sweetish accent but only until the sour kicks in. Sort of a date-like note, but at this point Im mostly searching for stuff thats underneath of the sourness, which is by far the dominant characteristic.

from tap at extreme beer fest 2017, boston. unclear dark copper pour, almost brown-orange, with a small light beige cap offering some retention and lacing. spicy red fruitiness, stone fruits, medium acidity - citric sharpness and acetic peaks; underlying caramel, wood, some coffee notes, plum vinegar, no particular treacle sugars. moderate carboantion, light body - oily; firmly tart spicy finish. not in belgian tradition at all, but a more than decent dark barrel-aged tart ale.

On tap at brewery in Berkeley a few weeks ago. Dark brown with lots of deeply dark fruit (plums, black currant), the funk, but a bit malty and chalky. A bit light and boring. I thought Wise Guise was a much better and more complex/interesting offering.

Bottle split at L42, big thanks to Leighton, 23/01/17.
Rich chestnut brown with a decent beige head.
Nose is tangy dark fruit rinds, pissy, wood must, vinegar, funk.
Taste comprises soured fruits, damp cloth, light spice, vinous, wood must, funk, fruit balsams.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, drying close with an acidic rasp.
Solid enough sour.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: From tap at the brewery. Copper brown color with off white head. Malty and yeasty aroma, bread, funky, tart fruity, dark dried fruits, wood. Acetic sour taste with salty notes. Medium oily body with soft carbonation.
On tap at the brewery. RateBeer Best bus tour 2017. Comes dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma of fruit, funk, and wood. Taste is fruit, berries, funk. malt, and oak. Very good. Very tart.

23rd January 2017Level 42 Bottleshare. Thanks to Leighton. Light haze on this reddish - amber beer, tidy cream colour head. Palate is airy, semi dry and has decent fine carbonation. Fairy tart. Fruity red wine vibe. Mellow vanilla. Light crispy finish. Nicely done, very drinkable.

Bottle at level 42, big thanks to Leighton! It pours hazy red - brown with a medium yellow - beige head. The aroma is musty, dirty, oak, vanilla, red fruits, cherry, fruit pie, cake, vinous and Victoria sponge. The taste is crisp, tart, tangy, sweet - sour, icing sugar, redcurrant, green apple skin, vinous, toasty, light toffee and good mouth - pucker. Medium body, moderate carbonation and foamy mouth-feel. Pretty tasty stuff.

EBF 2017. Crisp, effervescent, and refreshing, with some good fruit notes that pop up towards the end. But the main note that I had was -- wow, this is extremely sour. Big, low-pH bite that made me double check that all of my teeth were still in one piece.

Sample at EBF Saturday
Dark brown with a thin tan head. Tart deep pitted fruits with lots of earthy funk. slightly chalky mouthfeel. good but the other was much better.

Tap at the brewpub. Pours black, but not oily, rather a watery black. Aroma is strong oak, with roasted malts lurking behind. Body is medium, with a strong sourness and tartness, but it is well balanced. Fruity sour tart palate. Very nice.

Foggy, dark tea color. Good bomber, decent label. Tart, vinous nose. Way sour, gets you on the sides of the tongue and in the jaw socket. Lightish body, not highly carbonated. Pretty good, but a little one note. Thanks to Arina down at Proof.

22oz bottle shared at Level 42. Many thanks to Leighton for this one. It pours a clean ruby color with a small beige head. Aroma is rich in vinegar sour notes, tart cherries and oak. Taste is also sour and vinegarish and rich in sour tart cherries, framboise, oak and vanilla. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Overall, very nice

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2017 Bottle share at One Canada Square as The Rare Barrel Shadows of Their Eyes, 6%. Many thanks to LKS. Very dark orange or brown, almost opaque, foamy tan head. Aroma has some burnt toast, very dark toffee, resin. Body is frothy, soft carbonation. Taste has light vinegar, toffee, resin, light acidity, rounded malts, raisins and dates. Extremely drinkable for style. Not very sour. Very tasty.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2017 Bottle shared on Level 42 23/01/2017. Huge thanks to Leighton for this one. A ruby red amber coloured pour with a lasting beige head. Aroma is sour, rare barrel house character, caramac bar, lacto, citrus, little hairspray, hint of brown bread. Flavour is composed of semi sweet malts, tangy pithy lemon, sour, mellow puckering sour, low acidity, brown sugars. Palate is semi sweet and sour, moderate carbonation. Drying finish. 

Bottle shared at Ratebeer awards show. 30/01/2016. Huge thanks! A hazed golden orange coloured pour with a lasting off white head. Aroma is brown sugars, sour, brown bread, hint of vinegar. Flavour is composed of funky sour, hints of sweet, brown bread, vinegar, tangy red berries. Palate is sicky, sweet and sour, highish carbonation. Good.

Bottle shared in London / picked up in a trade. Pours clear copper-red with a frothy, off-white head. Leathery berries in the nose, some earth, sweaty funk. Light sweet flavour with moderate acidity, more tangy berries, leather, crackers, a little acetic burn, brown bread. Light-medium bodied with average carbonation. Finishes with moderate acetic twang, more tart berries, old leather, faint earth, salty sweat. Good depth. Solid overall.

Bottle from Hollingshead. Pours a dark color with a very thin tan head. Distinct sour aroma with some oak. Solid sour taste with some fruit complementing the flavor. Slight oak in the background. Amazing, amazing sour.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty spicy woody sour tart aroma with weak hints of caramel. Fruity sour tart woody flavor. Has a fruity sour tart woody caramel finish.

750 ml bottle poured a clear dark reddish brown with a lingering ring of tan foam. Aromas of roasted malt, cherry, cocoa and light coffee. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry tart finish. Flavors of berry, roastiness and light coffee with a crisp dry tart lingering berry finish.

Draught at 20th Pizza Port Strong Ale Festival. Pours dark brown with a small, frothy beige head, short retention with spare lacing. Aroma is moderate acetic cherries and raspberries with nutmeg, oak and bready malt. Flavor is bready malt, acetic cherries and raspberries with oak, nutmeg and a dry finish. Medium body and light carbonation.

Thank you Mathieu87 + PriorL for the effort! 750 ml. bottle sampled @ Samson en Geert Bierproef Avond. 2016 Vintage. Dark red amber with no head. Nose has pretty much the same profile as the 3 Rare Barrel beers tried at this tasting, this one leans even heavier towards vinegar, burning acidic, pure oak sour, low raspberry zest. Taste is pure acidic Rare Barrel, puckering, huge lemon, very acidic, raspberry gone vinegar, raspberry pits, raw vinegar oak, very sour & puckering, bit one note but quite pleasant if you like hugely sour & puckering beers. Vinegar, raspberry pits, acid body. Potent brew. Quite liked it but it wont be for everyone.
Bottle at WTWBA. Dark murky brown pour. Acidic brown sugar and sour chocolate. Really sour, dig this.
Bottle at WTWBA 2016. Dark murky amber pour. Sour dark fruit, hints of chocolate. Well made, very good.

750ml bottle thanks to Spence. Pours out a amber with some ruby red highlights and topped with a sand head. Nose is oak barrel tartness some berries and pit fruit. Taste is more of the oak funky tartness and a light fruit vinegar combo.

2014 bottle at dirty Matts, courtesy of the dirtiest of Matts. Dark mahogany with thin beige head. Mixed berries, some malt vinegar, oak, some dark coca powder, hints of brett and epson salt. Moderate body with a strong carbonation, dry and sour, finish is tart with berries.

Bottle: Poured a deep reddish/copper hue color ale with a nice off-white foamy head. Aroma of berry and oak with some tart and vinous notes is pretty wonderful. Taste is also a mix of tart and vinous notes with some berry and oak notes and very faint residuals sugar notes. Body is about average with good carbonation. Wonderful and I would love to compare this to Rodenbach.

A reddish copper ale with a thin mocha head. In aroma, sweet fruity malt with faint caramel, dark fruits, light mineral notes, light acidity, light Brett, very nice and complex. In mouth, a nice sweet lactic malt with light berries, tart cherry, light Brett, complex and beautiful. Bottle at Matts.
Bottle share at RBB. Pour is dark red/brown with a small off-white head. Aroma and flavor of dark fruit, oak, light chocolate, caramel, and sour mash.
Bottle - Rating 12,500 - pours dark reddish brown tan head - nose/taste of caramel, sour vinegar, cocoa and oaky acid - medium body

Bottle. Deep copper hue with good clarity and a fluffy cream-colored head. Aroma: cola, vanilla, brown sugar, a little toffee, a splash of cherry and balsamic. Flavor flashes with green oak fading to tannic acidity and a subtle toastiness. Really well-balanced, with tartness that never gets out of control.
Sample at HMOG. Oud bruin sort of cherry flavors with oak adding some body and complexity. Medium tartness. Bit of lactic acid. tasty and one of the better beers on the day.

Backlog, November 6, 2015
Heavy vinegar, starfruit, hints of saltyness and hops to it. Ok...

750ml bottle acquired via trade on BA. Thanks, bro. Excited for this one. Pours a nice deeper ruby brown hue. Darker middle, well hazed with cocoa toasty colors, the edges show a more burnt reddish tinge, nice glow with frothy tannish head atop. A decent layer, loose creamy film sticks around ok and laces sufficiently. Aromas are tart and funky, fleeting seeedy raspberry meets oak and funky brett. Earth, touches of tart fruit, dark fruit and subtle raisin. A bit of toasty malts, faint roast and biscuits beneath. More raspberry as it settles, more oak and funk, touches of darkness, depth of aromas. Initial is lighter bodied overall, some sharpeness and funk is a bit metallic, twangy with dust and cobwebs, wet basement and tart fruit appeal. Raspberries come in a bit, tannic skin and subtle earth. Mellow toasty malt, a bit carmelized with subtle cocoa. Tart, a bit more raspberry and sour jabs hit into the middle. Backend is dry, funky and oaky. Some vanilla, earth, balsamic and cherry appeal strikes nicely, tannic wine barrel, raspberry and red grapes, a bit bitter and growing tannic appeal as we finish up. Tart, dry and funky. This ends up really nice. I was a bit apprehensive at first but ovverall this one works pretty well. A bit toasty, biscuit, subtle cocoa malt bill adds some complexity. This worked pretty well. Solid nose, pretty pour, and a beer that has some real complexity.

Bottle shared by Adam, thanks! Pours a clear amber red with a near white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has dark red tart fruits with a bit of oak, funk and grain supporting. Flavor is nutty and oaky with a decent amount of tart fruits underlying.

Bottle, thanks to bytemesis. Yet again you send me something delicious. Clear dark red/brown pour with white head. Minimal lacing. Lots of chocolate, leather, cherry tart on nose. Well-balanced between sweet and tart. Medium body, average carbonation. Lovely.

Bottle shared at the 10th Annual Epic & Unusual Beer Tasting, 11/29/15. Hazy red, thin fizzy tan head, good retention. Aroma of tart cherries, peppery funk, wood. The taste is tart cherry, funk, wood, mild vanilla. Medium bodied, lingering tartness.

22 oz. bottle shared by jckp64 - thanks again, John! Pours a clear, deep amber color with a tiny khaki ring for a head. Notes of sour cherries, oak, apple liqueur, toasted sugar, red wine vinegar, and chocolate. Light-bodied, with a tart, acetic mouthfeel and modest carbonation. Assertively sour, indeed. It didnt stand up to the other Rare Barrel offering of the evening, but its good in its own right without being terribly complex or approachable.

November 5, 2015. Bottle, shared by Henrik och Carl 
Clear reddish brown with a very small tan head. Aroma is red wine vinegar, oak, hints of toffee, some dark berries, 
Taste is light sweet, sour, slight acetuc. Finish is dry, sour with red wine inegar, oak, light sweet berries and hints of toffee. Light bodied, dry but smooth, soft carbonation.
Alright, lacks dept and complexity.

Bottle courtesy of Henrik and Carl. Pours tiny hazy reddish brown with a small offwhite head that leaves a small trace in the glass while dissipating. Smell is slightly malty and tiny fruity with bread, caramel, raspberries, blackberries, balsamic vinegar, lemon juice, grape juice and moist hay. Taste is sour, malty and tiny fruity. Mouthfeel is dry, tart and medium bodied. Finish is sour with bread, caramel, crispbread, lemon juice, raspberries, balsamic vinegar, hay and lemon zest. But acetic but overall a solid sour brown.

(750ml bottle) Pours a deep amber body with a small cream head. Aroma of vinous, oak, berries, cocoa, and yogurt. Flavor of cherry, vinous, balsamic, raspberries, lacto, chocolate, and brett with a dry finish.
Bottle sample. Deep maroon color, off tan head. Aroma of dusty overripe berries, subtle cocoa. Taste is dusty, peppery plums and berries. Good stuff.
Bottle thanks to Shad, great tartness and sourness. Lots of vanilla and sweetness from the barrel. Unfortunately the body is thin which hurts it quite a bit.
From bottle. Could be more crisply sour if not for the somewhat cloying sweetness underlying the palate. Prominent dark grapes.

Tap at Apex, post CBC.

A: Dark red color thats near to purple, and an off-white head. 

N: Cherry, balsamic vinegar, acetone, leather, cabernet wine grape, oak, hint of olive, some tobacco leave, currant and maybe some fig.

T: Quite tart; light background sweetness.

M: Medium body, sharp carbonation, alcohol is hidden.

O: A complex goodie from Rare Barrel. Superior to Cascades offerings, such as Sang Noir or Sang Royale.
Tap at Apex in Portland. Pours dark brown with red hues. Aroma of wood, oak, vanilla, dark beries. Taste is rich flavor, light sour, flavorful throughout with a great finish. Overall, very good.
Bottle. Ruby brown pour with tan. Sour aromas, fruit, Brett and dark tones. Chocolate, fruit, sour flavors.
Bottle. Brett/lacto/oak dark sour. Chocolate and stone fruit show up on the nose too. Medium sour kick, light to moderate funk.
Slightly hazy light brown pour. Slight tan head. Sour fruit nose. Lightly tart taste. Cherry, stone fruits.

Aroma: Sour Dark Fruit, Plums, Mildly Bitter Cherry

Appearance: Deep Brownish/Reddish Hue, Passes Mild Light, White Head Ring, Some Lacing

Taste: Dark Plums, Cranberries, Bitter Cherry

Mouthfeel: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Bitter, Mildly Tart
Smells like a sour brown ale. Taste is medium sourness and mild malt. Tastes more like a sour red than, say, a sour stout. Medium sharp carbonation and medium body.

Sour aromas, traces of caramel malt, which mixes with elements of citrusy banana, dark fruit and a musty, funky chalk/ brett note. Creamy caramel creeps in underneath to add a malty backbone to the sourness as this lingers with finesse.

750, capped. Thanks, J! Pours a murky dark amber with a loose creamy tan head. Bright tangy nose showing oak, balsamic, a hint of strawberry quality, and some basement, maybe a bit of moss. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Balsamic, basement, strawberries, and oak on the mid palate. Long tangy dry finish. Beautifully balanced and approachable throughout.

[2/14/15] Draught at The Rare Barrel in Berkeley. Nice dark red color. Aroma of cherries, lacto, oak, cobwebs, funk, malt, a cookie-ish note and a vinegar hint. Sourish flavor, funky, cellary, with some lacto, some malt, a sweetish touch, cherries. Medium-bodied. Great stuff.

750ml bottle pours dark red ruby brown with light edges, finger of head. Nose is musty tart earthy leather and dried dark fruit, grape, light funk, dark cherry, a hint acetic at first but it opens up. Taste is crisp, medium palate, medium lacto sour acidity, earthy forest wood and dried dark cherry, grape, fruit, some vinous berry. Finishes mostly dry, musty oak, light medium funky dark fruit, leather and berry. Nice stuff.

Bottle shared thanks to JBPortland ! Pours a dull burnt umber color with two fingers of gaseous khaki foam. Layers of wet wood, tart cranberry, dark cocoa backdrop, tons of composted fruit, acidic punch and a lingering basement must that envelopes the whole palate in a suspenseful dark mystery like the best dark sours tend to do ! Delicious !

Tasted on 2/1/15 from a capped 750mL bottle from the first year membership. Pours hazy bright auburn with an average tan head that leaves spotty lace. The nose is malty red wine vinegar, and lightly nutty toasted vanilla oak. The flavor is vinous vinegar, same toasted malty, along with some brown sugar. The body is medium with lightly sticky tannin and a long sour toasted malty finish.

On tap Monks Kettle, San Francisco - CA. Color: clear dark brown beer with no carbonation and small white foam. Smell: fruity and barrel notes. Woody presence and toffee. Taste: nice sour taste with barrel equilibrium. Very complex beer not so easy to drink. Notes of caramel and toffee. Woody barrel finish. Aftertaste: sour and caramel.
A moderately sour darker beer. Hints of wood and chocolate, maybe a touch of dark fruit as well. Good but not great (for them!).

Rare Barrel tasting @ Malt Attacks, Brussels, thanks Pierre for sharing the bottles. 75cl de couleur acajou, col fin blanc-cassé.
Arôme au bouquet malté, plus prononcé que sur les trois premières bières, comme lindique sa couleur. Retrouve un fini acétique, brett-lacto avec un petit rétro biscuité.
Palais rappel un malt caramel, et de Spéculoos trempé dans le vinaigre et qui donne ce petit côté biscuité-grains. Le tout tirant plus vers une oud bruin au fruité noir de griotte

Poured from bottle to glass. Copper brown hue with fizzy off white head. Aroma is lactic, cherry, toffee, caramel. Mouthfeel is great with a light body and sharp carbonation. Taste is dry with a tart following. Overall this is a nice brew.

Draft at the Rare Barrel. Dark ruddy brown-purple color with big light khaki bubbles. The aroma is nice and wild, fruity with cherry, oak, vinegar, and leather. Good tart flavor, biting and crisp, rather acetic yet well-rounded and fruity. Medium-full body with a smooth feel and medium carbonation. Good beer!

Bottle... This beer rocks! Pours clear and brown with ruby highlights and no head. The aroma is acidic, woodsy and fruity  mainly cherries  but some chocolaty toastiness as well. Medium-bodied with adequate carbonation. Quite tart, featuring notes of cocoa and sour cherries. Finishes tart with some woody tannins. Kudos to 50belair for popping the top off this world class brew with the south Florida crew!

Medium brown with an off-white head. Aroma is malt vinegar, red fruits, dates, sour candy. Medium-light bodied, tart on the palate, sour fruity on the palate, acetic finish. Taste is malt vinegar, sour dark fruits.
Bottle share. Cloudy red/brown. Sour caramel, raisin. Taste is tart and sweet. Crisp, dry finish.
Hipster Nor Cal Especial. Love the oak, love the cellar woodie character, cloudy. Somewhat sour. This one has been on clothesline down south for only a scont. But well worth a try!

Bottle. Clear light brown pour with a fleeting off white head. Mild berry aromas. Tart berry highlights. Mild caramel, oak, and barrel lowlights. Good mouthfeel. A bit thin in the body but tasty. Vinegar.

Big tart, aroma...sweet tart, sour, fruity - cherry. Mostly clear, dark reddish brown. Sweet, sour, tart finish. Tart cherry fruitiness and some dark malt character to balance. Overall quite sour but a very smooth sour. Very drinkable...and "rare" of course.

Bottleshare thanks to DrewFace. Pours a dark brown, almost black. White head. Aroma is serious fruit, tart, cherry, yum. Taste is light bodied, sour, tart, get the dark fruit still, really yummy. Good beer.

750ml bottle. Im surprised at the rating because I like this but I woudl think most people would find it offensive. HEavy enamel ripping/burning lacto balsamic character to it and pretty much nothign else.

From short notes:

S- olive topanade, brown, butter oak lemon acidic acid. red wine tannins, brown sugar, mild cherry, a M- medium tacky and chewy body. Good carb. T- black berry, brown sugar, vinegar, sake, lemon, grass,mild dirt. Cherry. Ripe apple.

Bottle thanks to Russell. Pours a clear amber with small frothy white head that lasts. The aroma is strong oak, lacto, and dark fruits. Thin mouthfeel with strong lacto and oak with light dry sourness. Very good.

Bottle. Aroma is peach, lacto sour, oak, and some good funk. Great nose. Taste is nice sour and dry, clean finish. Some sour strawberry taste comes in at the finish. Great looking and tasting beer. I wish bottles were more available.

Bottle thanks to the folks at De Garde. Pours a brown/red color with a small white head. A big woody vinous nose, berries, Brett. The flavor is deep malty balance with sourness, funky at times, brown malt, a bit sharp sourness at times. Good.
From a tap at the brewery.The pour is a dark red with minimum white head . Theres a currant and chocolate with a foremost a sour taste .The texture is slick with a light body.
Reddish brown colored pour with a beige head. Balsamic, sour notes, Lacto, cherries, almost a chocolate/coffee note. Nice!!

Growler and on tap at rare barrel. Deep reddish brown color. Tart fruity aroma, lactic. Palate is lightly sweet with some drier notes. Tart cherry, oak, funk, mineral, charred wood. Excellent beer, on par with the Russian river beers in my opinion.

Tap at the brewery..Pour is dark redish brown with a thin off head..Nose is nice funk, dark soured fruit, berries, old forage, caramels, musty..Taste is nice tartness, funky berries, dark fruits and caramels

On draft at the brewery. It pours very dark red with an off white head. The aroma is black currant, cherry and dark malts with a touch of oak. The flavor is very sour with cherries, grape skin and some mild vinegar, but not as much as most of their other beers. My favorite of the night.

From tap at The Monks Kettle during "United Sours of America" (my first one from this brewery)

Clear dark reddish/brown with a small head. Sour and fairly vinous aroma and taste of oak, berries and brett. Refreshing and with a soft body.
Burgundy red. Minimal head. Nose is beets, root and balsamic vinegar. Cherries and blue cheese. Very acidic. Fruity like dark fruits, oak and melons. Just so much vinegar.

Growler. Pours a brown with an amber color. Slightly sour, with oak and caramel flavoring. Well balanced on that palate. Sweet!!!!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap @ The Rare Barrel. Cola colored pour with a khaki head. Caramel, blue cheese, and chocolate on the nose. Lots of balsamic notes, cherry cola, oak, and sweet caramel. Good sweetness to the flavor; plenty of cherry cola, chocolate, and caramel. Sour vinegar notes. A light funk of blue cheese as well.
On tap at the Rare Barrel tasting room. Clear burgundy pour. Heavy on the red wine vinegar with notes of cherry skins. Slightly watery, light bodied, and again extremely acetic.

Draft. Rich amber beer with a cream head. Malt and tart aroma with light red ine. Sour and light acetic flavor with light fruitiness/red wine and light oak. Medium bodied. Sour and light aetic notes linger with light oak and light red wine.

On tap at Ratebeer Gallery II. Dark rusty pour with a tan head. Dark sugars and lactic acid notes, dried fruits, plenty of oak. A nice dark sour that avoids the typical stylistic pitfalls of cola flavor and acetic acid.
On tap at ratebeer Gallery. Pours brown with redish head. Taste was extremely tart and sour. Makes you pucker on each sip. Had an oak finish
On tap at Rate Beer Gallery II, Pours cola brown with a pretty beige head and a sourish treacle aroma. There is a very sour dark fruit flavor leaving lots of brett on the palate. A pleasure to drink.
Tap at Gallery II: Beauty From A Barrel. Pours dark ruddy brown with little head. Acetic sour brown aroma. Full bodied. Flavor is pretty sour red/brown. Nice touch of red berry. Very nice drink.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2013 Tap @RateBeer Gallery II. Pours clear chestnut, small tan head, good lacing. Aroma is oaky, vinous, tart cherry, dried fruits. Flavor is a bit sweet at the beginning and very dry afterwards, vinous and lovely, medium plus tart.. Just a touch of astringence. Light bodied and very drinkable. Nice.

Aroma is medicinal, oak, sour. Appearance is dark red/brown. Taste is cherry, plum oak, hay, and clean lactic sourness. Body is medium with butterscotch and filmy layer. Overall very good

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Rich amber color. Very tart up front. Hints of raspberry, cherry. Caramel with acetic acid finish. Nice mouthfeel.

Hazy caramel reddish brown in color... Aroma of dark fruits, oak... Flavor is intensely tart up front, acidic, butterscotch, dark fruits, plum, cherries... Finish is oak, vinegar... Amazing

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Off tap at Beer Revolution. Pours a dark amber with a tan head. Aromas of chocolate and dark fruit. Tastes of tart dark fruit. Very Good!
